item.title: Sr. Manager, Archives | The Chickasaw Nation
item.description:
Sulphur, Oklahoma, Summary: The Holisso: The Center for Study of Chickasaw History and Culture is a 20,000-square-foot specialty library, focused on the study of the Chickasaw Nation and other tribes with ancestral homelands in the Southeast of what is now the United States. This facility provides access to the archives of the Chickasaw Nation Collection (CNC). It consists of over 2,500 cubic feet of government papers, legislative minutes, court cases, land documents, maps, newspapers, rare books, photographic material, audio-visual records and digital resources. Additionally, the CNC holds material cultural objects, archaeological collections and visual art both by and about the Chickasaw people. This position is responsible for arranging, describing, preserving and providing access to photographs, documents, and ephemera within the archives of the Chickasaw Nation Collection. Responsibilities: Supervises and evaluate the performance of archives staff of the Chickasaw Nation Collection Mentors and coach direct reports to develop their skills in both library operations and specialized areas, fostering their growth in a positive and proactive environment Ability to create, interpret, and apply written policies and procedures Ef?ciently manage correspondence, research inquiries, and multiple projects within deadlines Ensures the regular updating and submission of finding aids Reviews completed finding aids for adherence to standards and edit them as needed prior to publication Establishes processing priorities and determine appropriate levels of processing for collections, provide project management for processing activities, and set realistic goals and timelines for project completion Develops, refines, and enhances workflows and procedures for processing and managing collections in various formats, ensuring adherence to accepted archival standards and the unique needs of the Chickasaw Nation Collection Collaborates and frequently communicate with colleagues within Chickasaw Nation Collection to ensure processing practices support related functions such as acquisitions, preservation, digitization, metadata creation, public services, outreach, and instruction Maintains up-to-date documentation related to processing and description activities Facilitates outgoing loans of archival materials Supervises the use of collection management software, ensuring its effective application in managing archival materials Contributes to departmental outreach initiatives Participates in local and national professional organizations Assists in the execution of grants and research contracts Assists in the development and curation of the archives of the Chickasaw Nation Collection Researches, analyzes and evaluates funding opportunities Coordinates the planning, development and preparation of grant proposals for assigned departments Develops and performs detailed administrative tasks and functions to assure an accurate and timely flow of information needed for prudent administrative decisions Maintains files, logs, and records patron requests and other correspondence Maintains confidentiality, security, and integrity of data and information Ensures employees and resources complete assigned training and development Maintains knowledge of and enforces all laws, rules, regulations, policies and SOPs for assigned area, e.g. MICS, TICS, hospital standards, health codes, food sanitation, accounting principles, etc. Prepares weekly reports Assigns, reviews, monitors and ensures performance of assigned staff for area of responsibility Participates in candidate selection process Assigns tasks and responsibilities of assigned staff Reviews and documents work effectiveness of assigned staff Coaches and corrects assigned staff through performance deficiencies Observes and documents work behaviors of assigned staff Ensures cooperative and respectful work relationship of assigned staff including interpersonal training and resolving internal issues Ensures compliance with all laws, rules, regulations, policies, procedures and guidelines for assigned work area Performs all other duties as assigned Competencies: Essential: Able to follow instructions, both written and oral Ensures compliance Able to adhere to all scheduling and attendance requirements Must be able to work quickly, efficiently and accurately Focus on a single task for pro-longed periods of time Must be detail-oriented Must be self-motivated Ability to work independently Honesty, truthfulness, reliability, accountability Able to read, understand, apply, and retain knowledge of Chickasaw Nation, departmental, divisional and all other rules, regulations, policies, procedures and guidelines Knowledge of archival best practices, including conservation, preservation, and special collections procedures Knowledge of data content and structure standards for library, archival and visual materials collections Must be familiar with collection management systems and data input related to archives management Understand and working knowledge of Chickasaw and Southeastern art, culture and history Ability to multitask Establishes professional working relationships as appropriate Works well within a team Ability to plan, organize and follow through on assignments Must work under hard deadlines Ability to train individuals or small groups on specific tasks or procedures and engage with different learning styles Able to verbally communicate in a professional and positive manner with other team members, departments, guests and management Interpersonal skills to motivate, investigate, inspire Writes effective communications with team, departments, guests and management Keeps written records Skills: Essential: Proficient in Adobe Creative Suite including Photoshop, InDesign, Illustrator. XD and Cloud Basic Computer skills Must be familiar with the Microsoft Office Suite of products Skilled in operating a computer and/or other equipment related to specific role (i.e. automated currency counters, calculator, projector, binding machine, other related office equipment) Experience: Essential: 2 years directly related supervisory experience 5 years directly related experience Education: Essential: High School, GED or Equivalent Bachelors Degree in directly related field Nonessential: Masters Degree in directly related field Essential: Bachelor’s of Arts in Information Science and Technology (BAIS), or related field such as Library Science, Museum Studies, or History Nonessential: Master of Library and Information Science (MLIS), or equivalent advanced degree in a relevant field, such as Museum Studies or History   Credentials: Essential: Standard Driver's License Pass general background check CN Core Leadership Level 1 Working Conditions: Essential: Pass pre-employment drug test Visual acuity for detail, distance, color, depth perception Must be flexible with work schedule Sitting up to 50% of shift Walking up to 50% of shift Travels up to 25% Sometimes lift and or carry up to 25 lbs. We offer a full comprehensive benefits package including: Health, Dental, Vision, 401K, PTO, Life Insurance and more.

item.title: Archives and Special Collections Librarian | Colorado Mesa University
item.description:
Grand Junction, Colorado, SUMMARY Responsible for the management, selection, processing and preservation of books, manuscripts, archives, photographs and other materials within Archives and Special Collections. Selects materials for other academic departments as assigned. Provides assistance to individuals or groups locating and assessing information resources. Reports to Head of Technical Services. ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES include the following. Other duties may be assigned. - In consultation with supervisor, provides vision and goals for the Dept. and sets priorities. - Manages the daily operations of Archives and Special Collections. - Develops and maintains procedures, workflows, and documentation for the Dept. - Selects, accessions, processes, and deaccessions archival collections. - Manage collections using ArchivesSpace. - Identifies, digitizes, and contributes content and metadata to the digital archive using CONTENTdm. - Develops and manages Special Collections. - Provides research assistance and access to Archives and Special Collections. - Promotes use of collections through classroom instruction, displays, outreach, public presentations, tours, exhibitions, and marketing materials. - Develops online resources including LibGuides, tutorials, and departmental web pages. - Keeps abreast of archival management trends through participation in professional associations, webinars and/or publications. - Serves as library liaison to assigned academic departments by coordinating relevant acquisitions with department faculty as well as preparing library assessments for new courses, programs, and accreditation reviews. May include library instruction. - Contributes to committee work. SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES Recruits, selects, trains, and supervises student workers and interns.   QUALIFICATIONS To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE Required: - Master’s degree in Library and Information Science or Archival Studies from an ALA accredited institution. - Minimum three years of professional experience in archives/special collections performing duties such as appraising, accessioning, processing, preserving and providing access to archival collections Preferred: - Coursework relevant to archival management such as from library school or SAA. Knowledge of and experience using standards such as DACS, EAD, DCRM, MARC, and Dublin Core. Proficiency using an archival management system such as ArchivesSpace or Access to Memory (AtoM). Proficiency using a digital asset management system such as CONTENTdm. - Proficiency using MS Office software such as Word and Excel. - Proven record of strong service orientation and positive interpersonal skills. - Excellent written and oral communication skills. - Demonstrated ability to solve practical problems with effective attention to detail. - Demonstrates good judgement in decision making. LANGUAGE SKILLS Ability to read, analyze and interpret general business periodicals, professional journals, technical procedures, or government regulations. Ability to write reports, business correspondence, and procedure manuals. Ability to effectively present information. MATHEMATICAL SKILLS Ability to calculate figures and amounts such as discounts, interest, commissions, proportions, percentages, areas, circumference, and volume as related to fiscal management. REASONING ABILITY Strategic and analytical reasoning skills are necessary. Ability to solve practical problems and deal with a variety of concrete variables in situations where only limited standardization exists. Ability to interpret a variety of instructions furnished in written, oral, diagram or schedule form. PHYSICAL DEMANDS The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. WORK ENVIRONMENT The tasks involved with this position are typically performed in an office environment. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. The noise level in the work environment is usually quiet. About us: Colorado Mesa University is a mid-sized institution focused on providing unparalleled educational opportunities to students. Dedicated staff and faculty make CMU a place that is truly student-centered, committed to supporting students’ educational goals and journey. The library is a hub of academic activities and is deeply integrated into the campus. Located on Colorado’s Western Slope, the Grand Valley’s diversity of landscapes creates a stunning convergence of mountains, rivers, canyons and forests. Outdoor enthusiasts enjoy beautiful scenery and various outdoor activities without the high price, crowds and traffic of other destinations. Hiking, biking, skiing, fishing or floating a river are a short drive from campus. Grand Junction is a mid-size town that offers cultured amenities like a city symphony and chorale, craft breweries and wineries, art galleries, as well as music and theater productions. Excellent health and retirement benefits package: Click on the following link for more information: https://www.coloradomesa.edu/human-resources/benefits/retirement.html


Source: SAA Careers
